item.title: Germany fines Vodafone $51 million for privacy, security breaches
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Sergiu Gatlan reports: The German data protection authority (BfDI) has fined Vodafone GmbH, the telecommunications company’s German subsidiary, €45 million ($51.4 million) for privacy and security violations. “Due to malicious employees in partner agencies who broker contracts to customers on behalf of Vodafone, there had been fraud cases due to fictitious contracts or contract changes at...

item.title: Google: Hackers target Salesforce accounts in data extortion attacks
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Bill Toulas reports: Google has observed hackers claiming to be the ShinyHunters extortion group conducting social engineering attacks against multi-national companies to steal data from organizations’ Salesforce platforms. According to Google’s Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG), which tracks the threat cluster as ‘UNC6040,’ the attacks target English-speaking employees with voice phishing attacks to trick them into...

item.title: The US Grid Attack Looming on the Horizon
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Justin Ling reports: For years, cybersecurity professionals, watchdogs, and government agencies have warned that a malicious cyberattack on the US power grid could be devastating. With ample evidence that state-sponsored hacking groups are eyeing the decentralized and deeply vulnerable power grid, the risk is more acute than ever. Case in point: Hackers, believed to be...

item.title: US govt login portal could be one cyberattack away from collapse, say auditors
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Brandon Vigliarolo reports: The US government’s Login.gov identity verification system could be one cyberattack, or just a routine IT hiccup, away from serious trouble, say auditors, because it hasn’t shown its backup testing policy is actually in use or effective. The US Government Accountability Office reported Tuesday that Login.gov, which is managed by the federal government’s General...

item.title: Two Men Sentenced to Prison for Aggravated Identity Theft and Computer Hacking Crimes
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: There’s an update to a previously reported case. From the U.S. Attorney’s Office, Eastern District of New York, yesterday: Earlier today, in federal court in Brooklyn, United States District Judge Frederic Block sentenced Sagar Steven Singh, also known as “Weep,” to 27 months’ imprisonment for conspiracy to commit computer intrusion and aggravated identify theft. On...

item.title: 100,000 UK taxpayer accounts hit in £47m phishing attack on HMRC
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Nadeem Badshah reports: HM Revenue and Customs has lost £47m after a phishing scam breached tens of thousands of tax accounts, a group of MPs has heard. Two senior civil servants at the tax authority told the Treasury committee on Wednesday that 100,000 people had been contacted, or were in the process of being contacted,...

item.title: CISA Alert: Updated Guidance on Play Ransomware
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: CISA, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the Australian Signals Directorate’s Australian Cyber Security Centre (ASD’s ACSC) have issued an updated advisory on Play ransomware, also known as Playcrypt. This advisory highlights new tactics, techniques, and procedures used by the Play ransomware group and provides updated indicators of compromise (IOCs) to enhance threat detection. Since June...

item.title: Almost one year later, U.S. Dermatology Partners is still not being very transparent about their 2024 breach
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: U.S. Dermatology Partners, which has over 100 locations across eight states, recently posted a notice of a data security incident on its website. As stated in their notice: On June 19, 2024, USDP experienced a network disruption. Upon detecting the incident, we quickly took steps to secure our network, immediately initiated our incident response processes...

item.title: Oklahoma Expands its Security Breach Notification Law
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Melissa Pascualini of Jackson Lewis The Oklahoma State Legislature recently enacted Senate Bill 626, amending its Security Breach Notification Act, effective January 1, 2026, to address gaps in the state’s current cybersecurity framework (the “Amendment”). The Amendment includes new definitions, mandates reporting to the state Attorney General, clarifies compliance with similar laws, and provides revised penalty...

item.title: Ransomware group Gunra claims to have exfiltrated 450 million patient records from American Hospital Dubai.
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: A relatively new ransomware group calling themself “Gunra” has shown it has no compunction about attacking hospitals. They have reportedly locked — and have started leaking information from — the American Hospital in Dubai (AHD). In its first listing concerning this attack, Gunra claimed to have exfiltrated the entire Cerner Millenium database (now known as...
